Name: Designating September 10 annually as Big Daddy Kane Day in the City of New York and celebrating his influence on generations of Hip Hop MCs.
Title: Resolution designating September 10 annually as Big Daddy Kane Day in the City of New York and celebrating his influence on generations of Hip Hop MCs.
BodyName: Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

History.Description: This Resolution was Introduced by Council
This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
History.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

History.Description: This Resolution was Hearing Held by Committee
History.BodyName: Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

History.Description: This Resolution was Laid Over by Committee
History.BodyName: Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

Attachments.Name: Minutes of the Stated Meeting - May 11, 2023

Text:
By Council Members Oss�, Cab�n, Riley, Louis, Far�as, Rivera and Williams
      Whereas, Antonio Hardy was born on September 10, 1968, in Brooklyn and became one of Hip Hop's most skilled and influential MCs (master of ceremonies) and lyricists, known to his many fans as Big Daddy Kane or Kane; and
      Whereas, Kane is celebrated for his baritone vocal brilliance, with its quick flow and impressive rhymes, as well as his fashion trendsetting and command of the stage; and 
      Whereas, Although Kane grew up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, he became a member of the Juice Crew in 1986, a collective of acclaimed rappers hailing mostly from the Queensbridge housing projects in Long Island City, Queens; and
      Whereas, "The Symphony," produced by Juice Crew's renowned Marley Marl and featuring Kane, Kool G Rap, Craig G, and Masta Ace, was released in 1988; and
      Whereas, Rolling Stone magazine ranked "The Symphony" as 48 on its list of the 100 greatest Hip Hop songs and praised it for its "ferocious drum break and a snatch of Otis Redding piano," resulting in "a truly great late-Eighties posse cut," with the "smoothest flow" in the song attributed to Kane; and 
      Whereas, In 1988, Kane released his first solo album Long Live the Kane, ranked as 42 by Rolling Stone on its top 200 Hip Hop albums list, with Rolling Stone supporting the popular notion that Kane was "every MC's favorite MC"; and
      Whereas, Kane's hit single from that album, "Ain't No Half-Steppin'," was ranked by Rolling Stone as 25 on its top 100 Hip Hop songs list, with Kane praised as "the killer wordsmith of hip-hop's golden age," with "tightly coiled, extended metaphors" like this one: "Rappers, you better be/Ready to die because you're petty/You're just a butter knife, I'm a machete"; and
      Whereas, Kane's second album It's a Big Daddy Thing, his personal favorite album, followed just a year later and resulted in his nomination for best rap solo performance for "I Get the Job Done"; and
      Whereas, At the 33rd Annual Grammy Awards, Kane-along with Ice-T, Kool Moe Dee, and Melle Mel-won a Grammy for best rap performance by a duo or group for "Back On The Block," a track from Quincy Jones's 1990 album of the year of the same name; and 
      Whereas, "Show & Prove," the celebrated posse cut from Kane's 1994 album Daddy's Home, memorably showcased Kane trading verses with Scoob, Sauce Money, Shyheim, JAY-Z, and Ol'Dirty Bastard; and
      Whereas, Kane's long list of acclaimed songs also includes "Raw," "Smooth Operator," "Wrath of Kane," "Something Funky," "Young, Gifted and Black," "Mortal Combat," "Long Live the Kane," "Another Victory," "It's Hard Being the Kane," and "Warm It Up Kane"; and
      Whereas, Kane was honored as the sole guest star for JAY-Z's eight-show opening of Brooklyn's Barclays Center in 2012; and
      Whereas, Kane continues to light up stages decades later, performing his choreography and his songs, including "Set It Off," the one that he says "gives me energy, gives me drive"; and
      \Whereas, The innovators of Hip Hop, now in its 50th anniversary year, can look back on their many contributions to NYC's culture and economy; and 
      Whereas, It is appropriate to dedicate a day to honor Kane's influence as one of those innovators on the generations of MCs that have followed him; now, therefore, be it
	Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York designates September 10 annually as Big Daddy Kane Day in the City of New York and celebrates his influence on generations of Hip Hop MCs.



LS #12677
4/12/2023
RHP

\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj By Council Members Oss\'e9, Cab\'e1n, Riley, Louis, Far\'edas, Rivera and Williams\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Whereas, Antonio Hardy was born on September 10, 1968, in Brooklyn and became one of Hip Hop\rquote s most skilled and influential MCs (master of ceremonies) and lyricists, known to his many fans as Big Daddy Kane or Kane; and\par
Whereas, Kane is celebrated for his baritone vocal brilliance, with its quick flow and impressive rhymes, as well as his fashion trendsetting and command of the stage; and \par
Whereas, Although Kane grew up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, he became a member of the Juice Crew in 1986, a collective of acclaimed rappers hailing mostly from the Queensbridge housing projects in Long Island City, Queens; and\par
Whereas, \ldblquote The Symphony,\rdblquote  produced by Juice Crew\rquote s renowned Marley Marl and featuring Kane, Kool G Rap, Craig G, and Masta Ace, was released in 1988; and\par
Whereas, \i Rolling Stone\i0  magazine ranked \ldblquote The Symphony\rdblquote  as 48 on its list of the 100 greatest Hip Hop songs and praised it for its \ldblquote ferocious drum break and a snatch of Otis Redding piano,\rdblquote  resulting in \ldblquote a truly great late-Eighties posse cut,\rdblquote  with the \ldblquote smoothest flow\rdblquote  in the song attributed to Kane; and \par
Whereas, In 1988, Kane released his first solo album \i Long Live the Kane\i0 , ranked as 42 by \i Rolling Stone \i0 on its top 200 Hip Hop albums list, with \i Rolling Stone\i0  supporting the popular notion that Kane was \ldblquote every MC\rquote s favorite MC\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, Kane\rquote s hit single from that album, \ldblquote Ain\rquote t No Half-Steppin\rquote\fs12 ,\fs24\rdblquote  was ranked by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as 25 on its top 100 Hip Hop songs list, with Kane praised as \ldblquote the killer wordsmith of hip-hop\rquote s golden age,\rdblquote  with \ldblquote tightly coiled, extended metaphors\rdblquote  like this one: \ldblquote Rappers, you better be/Ready to die because you\rquote re petty/You\rquote re just a butter knife, I\rquote m a machete\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, Kane\rquote s second album \i It\rquote s a Big Daddy Thing\i0 , his personal\i  \i0 favorite album, followed just a year later and resulted in his nomination for best rap solo performance for \ldblquote I Get the Job Done\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, At the 33rd Annual Grammy Awards, Kane-along with Ice-T, Kool Moe Dee, and Melle Mel-won a Grammy for best rap performance by a duo or group for \ldblquote Back On The Block,\rdblquote  a track from Quincy Jones\rquote s 1990 album of the year of the same name; and \par
Whereas, \ldblquote Show & Prove,\rdblquote  the celebrated posse cut from Kane\rquote s 1994 album \i Daddy\rquote s Home\i0 , memorably showcased Kane trading verses with Scoob, Sauce Money, Shyheim, JAY-Z, and Ol\rquote Dirty Bastard; and\par
Whereas, Kane\rquote s long list of acclaimed songs also includes \ldblquote Raw,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Smooth Operator,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Wrath of Kane,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Something Funky,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Young, Gifted and Black,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Mortal Combat,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Long Live the Kane,\rdblquote  \ldblquote Another Victory,\rdblquote  \ldblquote It\rquote s Hard Being the Kane,\rdblquote  and \ldblquote Warm It Up Kane\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, Kane was honored as the sole guest star for JAY-Z\rquote s eight-show opening of Brooklyn\rquote s Barclays Center in 2012; and\par
Whereas, Kane continues to light up stages decades later, performing his choreography and his songs, including \ldblquote Set It Off,\rdblquote  the one that he says \ldblquote gives me energy, gives me drive\rdblquote ; and\par
\\Whereas, The innovators of Hip Hop, now in its 50th anniversary year, can look back on their many contributions to NYC\rquote s culture and economy; and \par
Whereas, It is appropriate to dedicate a day to honor Kane\rquote s influence as one of those innovators on the generations of MCs that have followed him; now, therefore, be it\par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\tab Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York designates September 10 annually as Big Daddy Kane Day in the City of New York and celebrates his influence on generations of Hip Hop MCs.\par
